Description: Lip sherd of Attic red-figured pottery lip-cup; interior: on the lip, red-figure decoration consisting of youth reclining to left, looking back (legs lost; lower body wrapped in himation decorated with crosses; dot for each nipple; large frontal eye; incision defining hair contour and wreath; red leaves on wreath); he holds a phiale decorated with two rows of dots in right hand and extends his left arm (hand lost) to right, the elbow resting on slanting cushion (decorated with two rows of black leaf-shaped lozenges with thick black line between); reserved groove under offset of rim; exterior: black at rim and black band just above junction with body; incised graffito in large letters.
Producer name: Near: The Painter of the Vatican Horseman
Curator's comments: For publication see also Cohen, B., 'Oddities of very early Red-figure and a new fragment at the Getty', Greek Vases in the J. Paul Getty Museum 4, 1989, 78, fig. 5; Klinger, S. 'Illusionist Conceit in some reclining Symposion Scenes painted by Euphronios and his Colleagues', Archäologischer Anzeiger 1997, 351, fig. 9.
Bibliographic references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum (E134.2)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0579) (Phase 1)
